case_name: Income-tax Officer, Gorakhpur v. Ram Prasad

facts.text: Appeals are C.A. Nos. 257 and 258 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C.A. Nos. 257 and 258 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated July 11, 1967 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal Nos. 319 and 320 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 11, 1967 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal Nos. 319 and 320 of 1962.

facts.text: Aggrieved by decision of Allahabad High Court in Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 1057 and 1059 of 1957, Income-tax Officer, Gorakhpur brought appeals after special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 1057 and 1059 of 1957, the Income-tax Officer, Gorakhpur has brought these appeals after obtaining special leave from this Court.

facts.text: First respondent Ram Prasad was the Karta of Hindu undivided family carrying business as Ram Nath Ram Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent Ram Prasad was the Karta of a Hindu undivided family which carried on business in the name and style of Ram Nath Ram Prasad.

facts.text: Assessments made on the family for income-tax for assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: Assessments were made on the family for income-tax for the assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48 and for excess profits tax for the companyresponding chargeable accounting periods respectively ending on

facts.text: Excess profits tax assessments for chargeable accounting periods ending October 28, 1943; October 16, 1944; November 4, 1945; March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: October 28, 1943, October 16, 1944, November 4, 1945 and March 31 1946.

facts.text: Income-tax assessment for 1944-45 and excess profits tax for period ending October 28, 1943 set aside by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal with directions for fresh assessments.

anchor.surface_text: The income-tax assessments for the assessment year 1944-45 and the excess profits tax assessment for the companyresponding chargeable accounting period ending on October 28, 1943 were set aside by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal with the direction that fresh orders of assessment be made

facts.text: On September 25, 1951, first respondent disclosed Rs. 2,08,450 under voluntary disclosure scheme and offered for taxation.

anchor.surface_text: On September 25, 1951, under a scheme for voluntary disclosure, the first respondent disclosed by means of an application a sum of Rs. 2,08,450 and offered the same for taxation.

facts.text: On October 1, 1951, Hindu undivided family disrupted with complete partition, accepted by department.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1951, the Hindu undivided family disrupted and there was a companyplete partition, which was accepted by the department as of that date.

facts.text: Fresh income-tax assessments made for 1944-45 to 1947-48 considering disclosures.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter fresh assessments to income-tax were made for the assessment years 1944-45 to 1947-48 taking into companysideration 1045 the disclosures made by the first respondent.

facts.text: No dispute about those income-tax assessments.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute about those assessments.

facts.text: On February 14, 1957, notices issued under s.13 of Excess Profits Tax Act to first respondent for four chargeable periods.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently numberices were issued under s. 13 1  of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act  on February 14, 1957 for all the four chargeable accounting periods ending on October 25, 1943,

facts.text: First respondent filed two writ petitions challenging validity of notices issued on February 14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately thereafter the first respondent filed two writ petitions before the Allahabad High Court challenging the validity of the numberices issued.

facts.text: Writ petitions are Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 1057 and 1059 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Misc. Writ Petitions Nos. 1057 and 1059 of 1957,

facts.text: On April 8, 1958, appellant issued three notices under s.15 of the Act to respondent for periods ending October 14, 1944, November 4, 1945, March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: After the institution of those writ petitions on April 8, 1958, the appellant issued three numberices to the respondent under s. 1,5 of the Act in respect of the chargeable accounting periods ending on October 14, 1944, November 4, 1945 and March 31, 1946.

facts.text: Writ petitions amended to challenge the three new notices.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the writ petitions filed by the first respondent were amended and the validity of those numberices was also challenged.

facts.text: Learned single judge allowed the writ petitions holding appellant not competent to take proceedings under Act post division of HUF.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single judge who heard the writ petitions allowed the same holding that the appellant was number companypetent to take proceedings under the provisions of the Act in respect of Hindu undivided family which had been divided.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Division Bench of Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by that decision, the appellant took up the matter in appeal to the Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court.

facts.text: Division Bench upheld single judge's decision.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench upheld the decision of the learned single judge.

facts.text: Special Appeal Nos. 319 and 320 of 1962 in Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 11, 1967 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal Nos. 319 and 320 of 1962.

facts.text: Section 2(17) of the Act defines person as including Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 17  of the Act defines a person as including a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: No provision in the Act similar to s.25A of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

It reads 4 1  Subject to the provisions of this Act, there shall, in respect of any business to which this Act applies, be charged, levied and paid on the amount by which the profits during any chargeable accounting period exceed the standard profits a tax ...

concepts.interpretation: Tax is levied on the business but the word 'paid' refers to the person, indicating assessment on the person carrying on the business.

anchor.surface_text: 14 1  The Excess Profits Tax Officer shall, by an order in writing after considering such evidence, if any, as he has required under section 13, assess to the best of his judgment the profits liable to excess profits tax ... Excess profits tax payable in respect of any chargeable accounting period shall be payable by the person carrying on the business in that period.

concepts.interpretation: Assessment and liability to pay excess profits tax is on the person carrying on the business during the chargeable accounting period; applies to joint business, partnerships, and legal representatives.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was competent to take proceedings under the provisions of the Excess Profits Tax Act in respect of a Hindu undivided family which had been divided.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single judge who heard the writ petitions allowed the same holding that the appellant was not competent to take proceedings under the provisions of the Act in respect of Hindu undivided family which had been divided. Aggrieved by that decision,

issues.text: Whether under the Excess Profits Tax Act, the tax is levied on the business irrespective of the identity of the person carrying it on such that partition of the HUF does not affect the competence to assess.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the appellant contended that in the case of Excess Profits Tax, the tax is levied on the business and not on any individual and therefore what is relevant is the continuation of the business and not the continuity of the identity of the assessee.

issues.text: Whether Section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, applied through Section 21 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, permits assessment against members of a partitioned Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: Next Mr. B. Sen, learned Counsel for the appellant sought to seek assistance from s. 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which section is one of the sections mentioned in s. 21 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the Excess Profits Tax Act contains any provision similar to Section 25A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, for assessment after partition of a Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Act similar to s. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

arguments.claim: The notices issued under s.13 and s.15 of the Excess Profits Tax Act are invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Immediately thereafter the first respondent filed two writ petitions before the Allahabad High Court challenging the validity of the notices issued.

arguments.court_reasoning: No competence to assess divided HUF under the Act due to assessment being on the person carrying the business and absence of post-partition provision.

arguments.claim: The appellant was not competent to take proceedings under the provisions of the Act in respect of Hindu undivided family which had been divided.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single judge who heard the writ petitions allowed the same holding that the appellant was not competent to take proceedings under the provisions of the Act in respect of Hindu undivided family which had been divided.

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmed as tax payable by person carrying business per ss.4,14; s.44 inapplicable to HUF; no s.25A equivalent.

arguments.claim: In the case of Excess Profits Tax, the tax is levied on the business and not on any individual and therefore what is relevant is the continuation of the business and not the continuity of the identity of the assessee; change of person irrelevant if business continues.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel for the appellant contended that in the case of Excess Profits Tax, the tax is levied on the business and not on any individual and therefore what is relevant is the continuation of the business and not the continuity of the identity of the assessee.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d Act Provided that references in the said provision, to the assessee shall be companystrued as references to a person to whose business this Act appl

arguments.court_reasoning: Word 'paid' in s.4 refers to the person; s.14(2) imposes liability on person carrying business in the period; s.5 links to income-tax chargeability; agreed with observations in Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. Jivraj Topun and Sons.

arguments.claim: Section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 applies via s.21 of the Act to impose joint and several liability on members post partition of HUF.

anchor.surface_text: Next Mr. B. Sen, learned Counsel for the appellant sought to seek assistance from s. 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which section is one of the sections mentioned in s. 21 of the Act. Section 44 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 reads thus Where any business, profession or vocation carried on by a firm or association of persons has been discontinued,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ce the matter beyond doubt that the assessment of the tax is on the person in the same manner as under the income-tax Act. No doubt under the Income-t

arguments.court_reasoning: s.44 applies only to firms or associations of persons; HUF is separate entity per s.3 IT Act classification and s.25A specific provision.

arguments.claim: There is no provision in the Excess Profits Tax Act similar to s.25A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 for assessment after partition of HUF, as it was not included in s.21 nor enacted separately.

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Act similar to s. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. ... For whatever reason it may be, the legislature did not include in s. 21 of the Act s. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 nor did it make any similar provision in the Act.

holdings.text: The Act contemplates assessment of the tax on a person though on the basis of the profits from a business. This conclusion receives support from s. 5 of the Act which states that the Act is to apply to every business of which any part of the profits made during the chargeable accounting period is chargeable to income-tax...

anchor.surface_text: The word paid in the context can only refer to the person. That is a clear indication that the Act contemplates assessment of the tax on a person though on the basis of the profits from a business. This conclusion receives support from s. 5 of the, Act which states that the Act is to apply to every business of which any part of the profits made during the chargeable accounting period is chargeable to income-tax under the provisions of sub-cl.  1 , sub-cl.  2  of cl.  b  of sub-s.  1  of S. 4 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 or of cl.  c  of that sub-section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'paid' in s.4 and liability under s.14(2) as attaching to the person carrying on the business during the period; links to income-tax chargeability via s.5; agrees with Madras High Court precedent.

holdings.text: We are in agreement with these observations. Consequently we are unable to uphold the contention that so long as the business continues, the change of the person who carries on the business is immaterial.

anchor.surface_text: 1  20 I.T.R. 143. 1049 We are in agreement with these observations. Consequently we are unable to uphold the contention that so long as the business continues, the change of the person who carries on the business is immaterial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly rejects argument that tax levied solely on business regardless of assessee identity, affirming personal liability on the carrying person.

holdings.text: This provision applies only to firms and association of persons. Hindu undivided family is neither a firm nor an association of persons. It is a separate entity by itself.

anchor.surface_text: This provision applies only to firms and association of persons. Hindu undivided family is neither a firm nor an association of persons. It is a separate entity by itself. That is made clear by s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which classifies the assessees under the heads individuals, Hindu undivided families,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.44 IT Act (applied via s.21 EPTA) limited to firms/associations; HUF distinct entity per statutory classification and need for specific s.25A.

holdings.text: That is made clear by s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which classifies the assessees under the heads individuals, Hindu undivided families, companies, local authorities, firms and other associations of persons. If Hindu undivided family is to be considered as an association of persons, there was no point in making separate provision for the assessment of Hindu undivided families.

anchor.surface_text: That is made clear by s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which classifies the assessees under the heads individuals, Hindu undivided families, companies, local authorities, firms and other associations of persons If Hindu undivided family is to be considered as an association of persons, there was no point in making separate provision for the assessment of Hindu undivided families. This conclusion is strengthened by S. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which provides for the assessment of Hindu undivided family after its partition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 IT Act treats HUF as distinct assessee class from firms/associations; existence of s.25A confirms separate treatment.

holdings.text: For whatever reason it may be, the legislature did not include in s. 21 of the Act s. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 nor did it make any similar provision in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is strengthened by S. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which provides for the assessment of Hindu undivided family after its partition. For whatever reason it may be, the legislature did not include in s. 21 of the Act s. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 nor did it make any similar provision in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit legislative omission of s.25A-equivalent or inclusion in s.21 means no mechanism for post-partition HUF assessment under EPTA.

holdings.text: The provisions of this section therefore place the matter beyond doubt that the assessment of the tax is on the person in the same manner as under the income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of this section therefore place the matter beyond doubt that the assessment of the tax is on the person in the same manner as under the income-tax Act. No doubt under the Income-tax Act the computation of the tax is on the basis of the income derived by a person from various sources, while under the Excess Profits Tax Act it is on the profits of a business of the person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.14 EPTA confirms assessment and payment liability on the person carrying business in the relevant period; no competence post-partition without specific provision.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax. Madras Jivraj Topun and Sons, Madras 20 I.T.R. 143

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax. Madras Jivraj Topun and Sons, Madras The point however is put beyond doubt by Sec- tion 14, sub-section  1  of the Act which provides for assessment of the tax after the return is submitted in pursuance of a notice issued under Section 13 of the Act. It requires that the Excess Profits Tax Officer, after completing the assessment should furnish a copy of such order (that is the assessment order) to the person on whom the assessment has been made

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. Jivraj Topun and Sons, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: The Excess Profits Tax assessment is to be made on the person carrying on the business during the chargeable accounting period; the tax is payable by that person; provisions of sections 13 and 14 make clear that the assessment and liability are personal to the person, in the same manner as under the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The word paid in the context can only refer to the person. That is a clear indication that the Act contemplates assessment of the tax on a person though on the basis of the profits from a business. This conclusion receives support from s. 5 of the, Act which states that the Act is to apply to every business of which any part of the profits made during the chargeable accounting period is chargeable to income-tax under the provisions of sub-cl.  1 , sub-cl.  2  of cl.  b  of sub-s.  1  of S. 4 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 or of cl.  c  of that sub-section.

We are in agreement with these observations. Consequently we are unable to uphold the contention that so long as the business continues, the change of the person who carries on the business is immaterial. Next Mr. B.

anchor.surface_text: That is made clear by s. 3 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which classifies the assessees under the heads individuals, Hindu undivided families, companies, local authorities, firms and other associations of persons If Hindu undivided family is to be considered as an association of persons, there was no point in making separate provision for the assessment of Hindu undivided families. This conclusion is strengthened by S. 25-A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 which provides for the assessment of Hindu undivided family after its partition.

We are in agreement with these observations. Consequently we are unable to uphold the contention that so long as the business continues, the change of the person who carries on the business is immaterial. Next Mr. B.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of this section therefore place the matter beyond doubt that the assessment of the tax is on the person in the same manner as under the income-tax Act. No doubt under the Income-tax Act the computation of the tax is on the basis of the income derived by a person from various sources, while under the Excess Profits Tax Act it is on the profits of a business of the person.
